instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hi I received a board with liquid damage in 2 areas 

1st Area:
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> in area <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TONB</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7441</CAPACITOR>) AND <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_ISNS1_P</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R7406</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7466</RESISTOR>) the resistors #’s are just to pin point area of corrosion 

2nd area:
<TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5314</RESISTOR>

I get a green light and quickly the light goes out in a split second.

I tested the 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 320 Kohms
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.79 Mohms

Lastly, I have another board here that chimes just has audio port issue. shouldn’t a 2011 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screen fit this model?  The lvds connector is silver ipex not gold ? Should I assume it’s 1680 x 1050? Or the standard resolution? It won’t go in so I’m assuming no. but I could’ve sworn I’ve tested another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in my test enclosure in the past. Anyway thanks in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Boards should be compatible.

You forgot to mention actual voltages for <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Do you get steady <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 1.7v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>= 1.7v
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> =0v
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS=0v

<RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR>=0v <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> 

Also on this board I know that <RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR> is reading “OL” <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is 180k so I know that <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is good. but I haven’t changed it till I resolve the issue that I suspect is on the 3.42V line. The mage safe flashes and instantly goes out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
You are missing even <SIGNAL>18V5_DCIN</SIGNAL>, what do you expect to get there???
How did you arrived to CPU power supply if no voltage at all on the board???
Did you check F6905 at least?

I can suppose input leakage, but is better to see eaxct ohm resistance for <RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>/86, measured onboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Yes F6905 is good same 1.7v at fuse
<RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR> =99.2k
<RESISTOR>R7081</RESISTOR> = 61.4k
<RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR> =468.3k
<RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> =330k

<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>= 3.2ohm
<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR>=20.5ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
There was a droplet of corrosion I cleaned up by <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> when I started also there’s some small corrosion by <CHIP>U7940</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> it’s like it hit all the best parts of the board :( 

honestly I was gonna change <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> as soon as I received this board but since its so close to u5701and j5800. I was hesitant. Even though I’ve done it before. it’s almost impossible for me to replace this mosfet without melting anything:(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Resistor values don't point to <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>; but still possible.
Try first another DCIN board.
Also check voltages using lab power supply and 85W cord.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Ok I’ll try another dc in board I’ve tried several. I have 2 original 85w chargers that I swap back and forth as my test chargers.
But I will prepare a 85w cord with lab power supply and tell you how much current it’s drawing later on today
Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
I don't want to know the current.
Lab power supply, or fake charger can show if there is a leakage problem on input stage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
The weirdest thing just happened I made the cord put it to my power supply and it chimed :/ but all my test chargers won’t boot with it. I put my test MagSafe and it MagSafe green light goes out immediately
It’s at 18.4v and drawing 1.13A  
I’m not sure what’s going on here these magesafe work on other boards I just tested 3 yesterday and all booted fine. Could the be a data line issue then ? Maybe the smc tells the charger to cut or adapter sense to cut?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message: Change <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and test again with original charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Ok, that worked. 
thank you very much.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message: Ok so I put it to several test and today the day it started doing weird things. It’s acting up there are weird artifacts on a YouTube web page but not on the desktop I will attach a image. I’m using 10600s as I can’t find 12800s memory could this just be a incompatibility issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Resolder <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> with leaded solder; use soldering iron.
Same issue on internal LCD and external monitor?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message: I’m gonna check external monitor now and let you know.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and  <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Resoldered <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> worked like a charm
Thank you sir
